title: Don't import whole lodash
body:
You're importing whole `lodash` module in your sources just to call one or two methods of it.
Either import individual packages (`lodash.forown`, `lodash.pick`) or change deps. to `lodash-es` and import like 

```js
import pick from 'lodash-es/pick'
```

Otherwise users of this library are penalised that their bundle.js contains whole lodash.js even if they're not using it.

title: After changing _.templateSettings.interpolate, old templates delimiters throw errors.
body:
If I change the interpolation options.  Like this:
`_.templateSettings.interpolate = /_ooo_([\s\S]+?)_ooo_/g;`
This works:
`var compiled = _.template('_ooo_foo_ooo_')({foo:'a'});`
But this throws an error:
`var compiled = _.template('_ooo_foo_ooo_ <%= bar %>')({foo:'a'});`
like this:
```
SyntaxError: Unexpected token =
    at Function (<anonymous>)
```

It's a weird use case but essentially I have a large string that gets decorated across several services on completely different machines.  I need to be able to fill out some details at one point and leave some to be filled out later.  I feel like ideally lodash should treat `<%=` as an unremarkable string, if I've changed it's interpolation options.

title: In .internal/stringToPath.js, the rePropName works weird...
body:
Hi~ @jdalton 

Since [this commit](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/5e38259044047c1a5f2e2e7010800872ed29a0f7),  the rePropName cannot match some path like 

```js
'a[0].b[0].c'
```
In `.internal/stringToPath.js`, the result is 

```js
stringToPath('a[0].b[0].c') // ["a", "0].b[0", "c"]
```

This is a pretty minor update but I sometimes see npm and yarn log files that are generated with the format `npm-debug.log.<randomNumbers>`. I'm not actually sure what causes this but it seems to happen to me when I'm in a location where my wi-fi reception is spotty.

This would prevent a file such as `npm-debug.log.123456789` from being added to the commit.

But what if I need the property object itself?

isEqual behavior
body:
**NOT AN ISSUE**
Just curious is it intended behavior to match primitives with their primitive objects.
`isEqual` matches primitives compared with their objects result

```javascript
_.isEqual(new String('abc'), 'abc')
// true

_.isEqual(new Boolean(true), true)
// true

_.isEqual(new Number(100), 100)
// true
```
shouldn't these be false ?

title: Support Asynchronous Iteratees
body:
When using lodash, we often have cases where we'd like iteratees to do async things. Most of the time, we can get away with things like `_.map` in conjunction with a `Promise.all`, but there are some cases where this falls apart. A great example of this (and the use case that triggered this issue) is `find` - I want to return the first item in a list that matches some async criteria, and support early exiting to avoid wasting computation when it's not needed.

Now that both native promises and async/await are shipped in all modern browsers and node, I think it's safe to say that it's here to stay as a core part of the JS ecosystem. Is there a plan to support asynchronous iteratees in lodash?

title: New function proposed: isUndefinedDeep
Add cycle function.
body: In most FP languages you have some way to cycle an array. Lodash unfortunately had no easy way of doing this, except abusing the existing function times and merge.

title: Looping over object collections containing a property "length" treated as array
body:
When trying to find out if any of an object's properties is undefined, you might want to use this construct:

    _.some({ a: 1, b: 2, len: 10 }, v => _.isUndefined(v))
    => false

Result: `false` (as expected). No undefined values.

But when the property `length` is used:

    _.some({ a: 1, b: 2, length: 10 }, v => _.isUndefined(v))
    => true // !!

Result: `true`.

The same problem with other functions:

    _.map({ a: 1, b: 2, length: 10 }, v => _.isUndefined(v))
    => [true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true]

(tested with v4.17.4)

Note: as a workaround, I used this construct:

    _.values({ a: 1, b: 2, length: 10 }).some(v => _.isUndefined(2))

body: Parameter name is `string` not `value`.

title: some question about .internal/assignValue
_.map is not throwing an error when undefined is passed instead it returns an empty array
Why does maxBy return an object instead of a number?
body:
I was surprised today when using `_.maxBy` for the first time to find that instead of returning a number, like `sumBy`, `meanBy`, and other functions do, `maxBy` returns the entire object that contains the max value.

I can see how some people may find that useful to have the object returned, but it could also be a bit misleading. There may be multiple objects that all share the maximum value, but only one of them is going to get returned. It seems more consistent with other lodash functions for `maxBy` to return a number, and in the event that the entire object was needed, the developer could specify in the next line of code the rules for getting the object[s] with the maximum value.

So I guess I'm wondering why the decision was made to return the object instead of the numerical value, and if it would be possible to change this behavior in a future release.

title: Missing `concatAll`?
body:
I'm just opening the issue here because Google didn't provide a "top hit answer" and a colleague wondered why there's a `mergeAll` but no `concatAll`.

Correct me if I'm wrong but imho the reason is you don't need it because it's already there:

```
const concatAll = Array.prototype.concat.bind([])
```

Please close the issue if that's all what needs to be said.

title: `Map` equality with `_.isEqual()`
body:
Hi. Please take a look at this:
``` javascript
const m1 = new Map([['y','x']]);
const m2 = new Map([['x','y']]);
_.isEqual(m1,m2); // true, SHOULD BE false
```
To be sure that `m1` and `m2` are different:
``` javascript
m1.get('y'); // "x"
m1.get('x'); // undefined
m2.get('y'); // undefined
m2.get('x'); // "y"
```
Thanks!

title: Unexpected _.uniq behavior when dealing with array of arrays.
Feature request: _.isNodeList()
body:
There is currently no method to check for the NodeList type.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/NodeList

NodeList objects are collections of nodes such as those returned by properties such as Node.childNodes and the document.querySelectorAll() method.

It can also be returned like so:

```
var parent = document.getElementById('parent');
var child_nodes = parent.childNodes; // the type of child_nodes is NodeList
```

lodash currently has all other "isXXX" types. eg. `isString()`, `.isElement`, etc.

For full coverage of types, I'd assume you would want NodeLists. You already support browser-specific methods like `_.isElement()`

title: _.get and _.set sometimes treat a string number for an object key as an array element index
Add missing keysIn import for baseClone.js
body: `baseClone.js` has a dependency on `keysIn` used when the `CLONE_FLAT_FLAG` is set. This does not effect the public facing api since, currently, no `lodash` methods use the `CLONE_FLAT_FLAG`. However, it can still cause some build processes to fail (the google closure compiler for example).

title: Add ability to start _.flow() with an expression
body:
I'd like to be able to do elixir-pipe-operatoresque flows, like this:

    _.flow(1,
        x => x + 1
        x => x * 5)()

so that I wouldn't be required to look at the lower right to find the parameter, but find it right at the beginning of the chain. I am aware that I could just use `_.constant` or an arrow function like `() => 1`; however, maybe there is a chance that expressions might become allowed as the first parameter? Maybe someone in here has an alternative proposal?

Thoughts?

title: toNumber(null) returns 0
body:
The **toNumber** function returns `NaN` if given `undefined` or a string that doesn't parse as a number. And, as expected, `toNumber(1)` and `toNumber(0)` return `true` and `false` respectively. However, I was extremely surprised to find out that `toNumber(null)` returns `0`.

In my understanding, null means "no value provided", which is quite distinct from the value zero. For example, if you're working with the value of a currency field in an API response, you might expect the value to be a valid number (or a number as a string) or null. I might use `toNumber(cashAmount)` to make sure I was working with a number value before doing arithmetic. This could be extremely problematic for obvious reasons.

Is this the intended behaviour of the function? And, if so, why?

P.S. If not, I'm happy to submit a PR.

title: lodash-es modules should be published to NPM with ".mjs" extension
body:
Using lodash-es 4.17.4, if I try to run the following file in Node 8.5.0:

test.mjs:

```js
import {map} from 'lodash-es';
```

```
node --experimental-modules test
```

Then the following error occurs:

```
SyntaxError: The requested module does not provide an export named 'map'
    at checkComplete (internal/loader/ModuleJob.js:86:27)
    at moduleJob.linked.then (internal/loader/ModuleJob.js:69:11)
    at <anonymous>
```

This is because the files published to NPM do not have the ".mjs" extension.  Can you please publish the package with the files with Node-compatible extensions so the package can be used natively?

Ex:
```js
_.ensureRight('/some/path', '/')   // '/some/path/'
_.ensureRight('/some/path/', '/')  // '/some/path/'

_.ensureLeft('github.com', 'https://')         // 'https://github.com'
_.ensureLeft('https://github.com', 'https://') // 'https://github.com'
```

title: Wrong documentation or wrong behavior of _.defaultsDeep with empty arrays (different from the _.defaults one)
body:
An empty array is not undefined:

```
â–¶ nodejs
> let a = {b: []}
undefined
> a.b
[]
> a.b === undefined
false
> a.c === undefined
true
> 
```

`_.defaults` documentation (which `_.defaultsDeep` refers to) says `Assigns own and inherited enumerable string keyed properties of source objects to the destination object for all destination properties that resolve to undefined.`

Nonetheless, empty arrays are always overwritten in `_.defaultsDeep`:

```
_.defaultsDeep({a: []}, {a: [1]})
Object { a: Array[1] }

_.defaultsDeep({a: [1]}, {a: []})
Object { a: Array[1] }
```

while they are not in `_.defaults`:

```
_.defaults({a: [1]}, {a: []})
Object { a: Array[1] }

_.defaults({a: []}, {a: [1]})
Object { a: Array[0] }
```

I see that `_.defaultsDeep` uses `_.mergeWith`, and then I understand the behavior, but still I think `_.defaults` and `_.defaultsDeep` should have the same behavior or the difference in the behavior should be well documented

title: [lodash-cli] Support custom extensions

Maybe is good to parametrize this setting with a parameter, so ES Modules version works natively in Node.

title: Why does the function work differently with the type conversion?
body:
```
lodash.subtract(5, 3)   # => 2
lodash.subtract(5, '3')   # => 2
lodash.subtract('5', '3')   # => 2

lodash.add(2, 3)   # => 5
lodash.add('2', 3)   # => 23 -- ???
```

I use the 'subtract' as an automatic type conversion when performing operations. I would like that the 'add' also converted the string into a number, if suddenly it accidentally hits.

This would put it more in line with traditional data structure behavior: Getting the node at "empty path" within a tree should return it's root in my book. But maybe there are other considerations at hand?

Is there a reason for the extra `index &&` in [baseget#L21](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/.internal/baseGet.js#L21)?

What about:

```js
return index == length ? object : undefined
```

instead of:

```js
return (index && index == length) ? object : undefined
```

?

title: lodash/fp flatMap doesn't behave as regular flatMap : only the value is passed to the iteratee

Don't know if this is intended or not, but `flatMap` in `lodash/fp` doesn't pass extra args to the iteratee func.

As you can see in the regular `lodash` flatMap receive the extra arg :

Step to reproduce : 
```sh
âžœ  bin git:(next-cli) âœ— node -v
v8.2.1
âžœ  bin git:(next-cli) âœ— node
> const _fp = require('lodash/fp')
undefined
> const _ = require('lodash')
undefined
> _fp.flatMap((v, k) => console.log(v, k))({a: 'b'})
b undefined
[ undefined ]
> _.flatMap({a: 'b'}, (v, k) => console.log(v, k))
b a
[ undefined ]
> _.VERSION
'4.17.4'
> _fp.VERSION
'4.17.4'
```

body:
The doc should be changed: random --> pseudo-random.

Wherever the word random is used, it should be changed to pseduo-random.

_Produces a pseudo-random number between the inclusive lower and upper bounds._

This method uses the Math.random method which returns pseudo-random numbers.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math/random

There's a huge difference between a random and pseudo-random number.

A computer is not able to generate random numbers and it's not even possible to prove that a sequence of numbers is random or not.

title: Fixes bitmask param type
body: Bitmask is number

title: Integrity corruption with string case conversion?
body:
Hi, I'm confusing a little by this results:
```js
_.snakeCase(_.camelCase('geo2_json')) !== "geo2_json" // true, result is geo_2_json
```

I found it is not expecting result...
Maybe adding of additional parameter like `skipNumbers` should help?

```js
_.snakeCase(_.camelCase('geo2_json'), true) === "geo2_json" // true
```

title: Outdated standalone functions on npm
body:
Hi, I saw on npm that the standalone function packages are not up to date compared to the ["full" lodash](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash) package. For example, [omit](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash.omit) is at version 4.5.0 whereas I can see in the changelog that it has been updated a couple times since this version.

Would it be possible to update these standalone packages on npm (pretty please)?

title: new functions: find value in collection and create array based on references
Iteratee capping inconsist in Lodash FP
body:
Lodash version: 4.17.4

Lodash fp's default behavior is to cap iterates, but sometimes this isn't respected.

This for example works:

```js
_.map(parseInt, ['6', '8', '10']);
```

But this doesn't:
```js
const log = [];
_.map(log.push.bind(log), ['foo', 'bar']);
console.log(log); // ["foo", 0, Array(2), "bar", 1, Array(2)]
```

Capping can be forced with `convert({cap: true})`

```js
_.each.convert({cap: true})(console.log, ['foo', 'bar']); // Will log 'foo' and 'bar' only
```

Capping "_" doesn't change anything (which makes sense I guess, since this should already be the default)

```js
_.convert({cap: true}).each(console.log, ['foo', 'bar']); // Will log `["foo", 0, Array(2), "bar", 1, Array(2)]`
```
I can't seem to grasp how this could be intended, but perhaps it is?

title: master branch of lodash.sampleSize having incorrect code
body:
I copied the code from https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/sampleSize.js and ran it in my local machine. 
Two issues found:
1) The length of 'array' and length of 'result' are same which is incorrect. The length of 'result' should be n
2)random selection happen within first n elements which is incorrect. The random selection should happen in entire array. Please check the attached snapshot for the code and output. During each run, the first 3 values get swapped and the last 3 values remains same.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29668266/30025040-541dfed0-9194-11e7-9636-b6cfe3275efd.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29668266/30025223-12a7618e-9195-11e7-8f57-b6acba7c1b2b.png)

title: Fix baseXor implementation
body:
baseXor and its dependents were changed on commit
729d1a57aa77a9c82c8292dcfa0054e4b90060b1, based on issue #2758.

But the previous implementation was correct, which respected the
properties of the algebra.

The symmetric difference of two sets is the union of both of their
relative complements, and it is commutative:

`A Î” B = (A âˆ– B) âˆª (B âˆ– A)`

`A Î” B = B Î” A`

In that respect, both implementations were equivalents, the problem
appeared when you tired to xor multiple sets, since the new
implementation didn't respect the associative property:

`A Î” (B Î” C) = (A Î” B) Î” C`

```javascript
const a = [1, 2, 4, 5]
const b = [2, 3, 5, 6]
const c = [4, 5, 6, 7]

_.xor( _.xor(a, b), c )
// [1, 3, 5, 7] (correct)

_.xor( a, _.xor(b, c) )
// [1, 3, 5, 7] (correct)

_.xor( a, b, c )
// [1, 3, 7] (wrong)
```

With this fix, the associativity is respected:

```javascript
_.xor( a, b, c )
// [1, 3, 5, 7] (correct)

```

See:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_difference
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exclusive_or
https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/84184/relation-between-xor-and-symmetric-difference

title: Changing Case with plural initialisms
body:
Attempting to change case with plural initialisms results in an unpleasant result.

For example `_.kebabCase('orgUUIDs')` becomes `org-uui-ds`. Expected output would be `org-uuids`.

See https://runkit.com/gidgidonihah/lodash-case-initialisms for examples across all case changing functions.

title: Async chainable functional operators
body:
Hi,

I was wondering if there are any plans of supporting chainable async operators on Lodash or in a sibling project in order to be able to better leverage async/await in a functional manner now that it's natively supported in a good chunk of browsers.

Cheers!

title: Can not use this in _.forIn - resolves to undefined
feat(defaultTo): allow multiple default values
body:
This allows `defaultTo` to accept multiple arguments `defaultTo(value, default1, default2, ..., defaultN)` returning the first value to pass the existing `defaultTo` check.

This should remain a non-breaking change and should be backward compatible with existing functionality.
